Situation1: They scan items during a slow afternoon with a few customers in line.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story:
I stand behind the register, scanning groceries for the handful of customers waiting in line. It’s a slow afternoon, and I’m grateful for the calm, but my mind is elsewhere. My break is coming up, and I plan to use it to vote at the polling station across the street. When my relief finally arrives, I hurry over, ballot in hand, determined to do everything right. At the table, a poll worker frowns at my envelope. “The signature smudged,” she says gently. “Could you re-sign it so your vote isn’t rejected?” 

I freeze. My break is almost over, and I know the store expects me to be back on time, ready to process transactions accurately and keep the line moving. But here, as a voter, I’m expected to follow every instruction, to make sure my ballot counts. I feel the pressure mounting—if I rush, I might mess up again, but if I take too long, I’ll let my coworkers down. My hands tremble as I stare at the pen, caught between the demands of my two worlds, unsure which expectation to meet first.
